author: @larryhatcher8927
text: Great video...even though I was annoyed by 2 commercials in a 9 minute video.  In any case I really liked the idea of developing projects.  The amount of work that you need to do (that is if you want to do it right) is staggering but, I believe, it would be worth it.  The main problem I have is that I'm a bit older then most of the people applying for these positions.  I have a Masters but none of my education involved Date Science (short of a couple of Statistics and Decision Science classes).  All of my analytics training has been done on my own time.    I find very few jobs listed as "Entry Level Data Analyst".  Most if the jobs I see on Indeed start with 5 years experience.  I like the idea of creating a Linkedin page.  I have an account but I don't really use it.  Last thing......Learning Python....that is a very ambiguous statement.  You can learn the basics in two weeks.  The important thing is to get your basics down and then know where to go for the rest

author: @donnelly5757
text: This video gives me a lot of hope in regards to what I have been learning and what skills I acquired in graduate school even if my degree is not on par with some of the more quantitative degrees out there! With having spent over three years in college to do undergraduate and graduate level projects including my thesis using Excel and SPSS, I think with some quick review, Excel should not pose an issue. This fall I am taking an Oracle Database 12c Administrator Associate Certification course which I'm assuming I will learn more advanced SQL queries along with some other DBA skills. At the same time, I will be learning Tableau and Power BI on my own. I hope 2021 is the year I finally land a solid entry level job.

text: Great video sir... regarding going back to school for a masters 6:00 , not always necessary but if one does I am of the opinion that employers respect that more that one goes to school in their 30's or 40's as a working professional versus someone that did it in their early 20's.  My humble opinion is that it shows maturity and dedication to the profession.
